children.value: This page will show you how to use colonyJS to connect to the network, create a token, create a colony, and make a payment. We will be using the
test network, so make sure you have an Ethereum wallet with some test Ether before getting started. If you have never created a wallet or requested test Ether, check out
For this example, you will need the following tools:
Open up your terminal and move to your project directory. You can create a new project or use an existing project. If you create a new project, you will need to run
Note: If you are using an existing project that uses
or you would prefer to use
, feel free to do so, just bare in mind that you will need to substitute the
commands throughout the instructions provided here.
You will need to install the following packages:
Install the packages with the following command:
In this example, you will create a simple script that runs in the terminal with
. The script will run through the necessary steps to connect to the network, create a token, create a colony, and make a payment.
file in the root of your project and add the following code:
First, you will need an instance of your Ethereum wallet. In this example, you will use
. We recommend using a wallet that you strictly use for testing.
// Check out the logs to see the wallet address
Next, you will need to use your wallet instance to get an instance of the network client.
// Check out the logs to see the network address
Each colony has a native token. The next step will be creating the token that will be assigned to your colony.
// Create a token using the network client instance
// Check out the logs to see the token address
Now that you have a token, you can create a new colony.
// Create a colony using the network client instance
// Check out the logs to see the colony address
You have used the network client to create a token and create a colony but now you will need to call methods specific to your colony, which will require the colony client.
// Get a colony client instance using the network client instance
In order to use the extended payments feature, you will need to grant permission to the
// Set an admin using the colony client instance
You now have a colony with a native token and the extended payments feature is enabled. The final step is making a payment.
// Make a payment using the colony client instance
You now have all the example methods you need to connect to the network, create a token, create a colony, and make a payment but before you execute the code, you will need to change
example. We recommend using the private key of a wallet that you strictly use for testing.
You are all set! All you need to do now is run
in your terminal, which will connect to the network, create a token, create a colony, and make a payment using colonyJS.
